nodes.body:
The word that best describes my emotional state tonight is "Schadenfreude." ¬†There is no word in English that says it so eloquently.

For years I've watched as Trump the bully had his way, using his power as President to grab and grift, and at the same time to inflict misery on the innocent. ¬†Those kids in cages . . . . .¬†

This week posed some interesting questions to ponder...

If Trump is the defacto leader of several domestic, militant groups, why does he need Secret Service protection? The only person in government not threatened this week was Trump.

If the FAA and FBI can ban flyers they believe are threatening violence, why can't Twitter ban posters doing the same?

Why does it take more education and experience to teach first graders their ABCs than it does to become a member of Congress and make and pass laws?

nodes.body:
How do I hate you, Donald Trump?
I hate you to the depth and breadth and height my soul can reach.

For every lying, whiny tweet,
May your fame putrefy like a carcass on a beach.

For every brave officer struck down,
May you forever be run out of town.

For every child you put in a cage,
May you endure the parents' anguished rage.

For the security force you caused to sleep tonight far from home,
May you be hated in your own.

For all the fun you made of warriors,
their parents steeped in grief,
and journalists brave and true,
May the humiliation you meant for them¬†
Instead be heaped on you.

Apologies to Elizabeth Barrett Browning

nodes.body:
2 Virginia police officers face federal charges in Capitol riots

According to a criminal complaint, Robertson and Fracker were photographed inside the Capitol building in front of a statute, with one seen pointing and the other making an obscene gesture. At the time of the riot, the two were off-duty from their jobs as police officers with the Rocky Mount Police Department, the complaint says.

The photo was shared initially only with other members of the Rocky Mount Police Department, but Robertson re-posted it to his own Facebook account after others shared the photo on social media, according to the complaint. In a comment on social media, Robertson allegedly said he was "proud" of the photo because it showed he and Fracker were "willing to put skin in the game," the complaint said.

https://www.cbsnews.com/news/capitol-riots-virginia-police-officers-arrested/

The dummy posted the incriminating evidence on Facebook, and he's proud of it. He's proud that he participated in a violent attack with a mob that injured over 60 cops, killed one, and drove another to suicide.

The FBI needs first to fumigate the white supremacists from its own ranks, and then to find all of them in the ranks of American police departments, where there are obviously more than a few.

nodes.body:
Eric Trump acts as though he entered the business world yesterday when he tries to blame the 'cancel culture' (whatever that means) for the Trump organization's business failures.¬† Let's consider:
1.¬† Every single business venture Donald Trump puts his name to or interest in fails, most sooner rather than later.
2.¬† Donald Trump does everything he knows how to make people hate him, specifically carving out entire groups of people to spew venom on.¬† Who does business with someone they know hates them?¬† Trump even recklessly maligned GM and Carrier over decisions he didn't like.¬† Give me a break.
3.¬† Donald Trump and his businesses run up huge debt--Other People's Money--and gets bankers to float him loans even when bankers know they are unlikely to be repaid.¬† Well, here's a lesson for Eric:¬† eventually, the debts get paid and they get paid by the borrower.¬† Time is now for Trump to pony up.
4.¬† Trump screws customers on prices even using the prestige of his office to try to rake in money.¬† His DC hotel set Inauguration Day prices at around $2,200. per night.¬† The day after he was sworn in to office in 2017, he increased the initiation dues by 100% at Mar a Lago.¬† Everybody in business knows that everybody else is trying to rob them, but we all know that we are not going to be shown to be suckers while we're getting fleeced.
5.¬† What does Trump and the Trump Organization sell that consumers (and even other businesses) actually want?¬† Steaks? Poorly made Wine?¬† Seats on a Trump airline that has had maintenance? An extraordinarily high-priced education in real estate flipping at Trump U that anyone can get off the internet or by talking to the 20 year-old high flying classmate of your son who has failed at anything because he just got lucky at the start.

Eric Trump is just like his old man--he loses at everything he tries because he is not honest, avoids hard work, borrows even when he can pay himself, and is not nice to people.¬† I wonder why business ain't good?¬†

nodes.body:
The amazing thing is that if Trump had been just halfway competent at his job, had listened to the medical experts on COVID, had not decided to make mask wearing a political wedge issue, he likely would have been re-elected.

No-one blames him for COVID. But he does get blamed for the incompetent response to it, and for making us the world's leader in virus deaths and cases.

And if he had accepted his election loss gracefully, as every other President has done,¬† conceded, congratulated his opponent instead of whining and lying, and, finally, inciting a deadly insurrection designed to overturn the results, he could have left office as one of the world's most famous people, made a fortune on the speaking circuit, kept his tacky real estate properties going, held his grip on the Republican party, and maybe even run again for President in 2024.

Now he's disgraced. Shunned.

He blew it. Bigly.

nodes.body: As usual, McConnell is calling the shots and having it both ways. He can simultaneously seem to oppose the violence--by saying he'll "consider" impeachment--while actually not opposing it by refusing to call the Senate to session early to hear the case. By the time of the inauguration, the country will want to move on, and McConnell won't have to take a stand. The purpose of the impeachment was to remove Trump from office and from his access to the power he may wield to create more harm. McConnell also refused for weeks to acknowledge the free and fair election by congratulating Biden, refused to call out the President's lies on voter fraud, and only depicted the US democracy as endangered--near a "death spiral"--at the last possible moment. He also lead the the Republican Party in its racist attacks to block and reverse any legislative achievement by the Obama Administration and silenced the voice of the people himself when he refused the duly elected President from fulfilling the duty to appoint a Supreme Court Justice. In other words, I wish the media could be a little less breathless reporting every time McConnell winks across the aisle.¬†

While this was all well deserved and I have zero sympathy for Trump, I do worry about his state of mind and what he might do before the 20th. We already know he doesn't care about the country or American people, so who knows how he's going to take out his rage, I only hope that those that surround him can stop him if he strikes out.

I almost (but just almost) wish he was still on Twitter so at least we'd know what he's thinking since he has no filter and tweets anything and everything in his mind.
